pros: A pleasing community to live in camp. Pleasantville Arizona... Don't rely on getting across to Bahrain easily, as so are 40,000 others - and it really doesn't have much to offer. Lot's of interesting projects to work on, with very nice Saudis. Warm and pleasant, humorful and non-judgmental. Surrounded by well educated and generally pleasant colleagues from all over the world, who have a great community social life. Everything is only 5 minutes away if you live in camp. Opportunities abound for those who are willing to be agile, productive and positive. A good and surprisingly large hospital, in the camp. Many excellent Saudi staff, surgeons etc.
cons: Many people will arrive on there first day at work to be told that they don't have the role they've been contacted for. Bit frustrating after a year to get gain the position and actually get there. Managers move around and the info doesn't always get to the replacement. You still get paid though. If your managers really don't want you after you have arrived, they may play the 'don't give her any work' game. Then as you have been sitting around twiddling your thumbs they'll call you in on your 90th day and tell you that you've failed probation because you haven performed, so go home again and pack. Managers often can't make decisions and don't read for more than 30 seconds - which may mean a shift in your expectations - or you can just allow it to irritate you; or you can just carry on and smile. The camp families tend to be a bit cliquey, so if you don't fit their social circle you could be politely avoided. Specific religious beliefs, married or single, that kind of clique. Don't expect a reference when you leave - they just don't give you one, unless you personally request from a friendly manager. It's difficult to come back into the real world if you have been there for 5 years or more, as your overseas experience will be probably ignored by recruiters.
